claim.text: Text-based and multimodal approaches outperform purely price-based methods for short-term and long-term volatility prediction.
claim.exact_quote: Table 2 shows how both text-based and multimodal approaches consistently outperform methods that are purely based on historical pricing, for both short-term (n = 3) and long-term (n = 30) volatility prediction.

evidence.evidence_text: Text-based and multimodal approaches significantly outperform purely price-based methods for both short-term (n = 3) and long-term (n = 30) volatility prediction.
evidence.limitations: Limited evidence on medium-term predictions; performance for medium terms (n = 7, 15) is comparable between methods excluding HTML.
evidence.location: 6.1 Comparing Price-based Methods with Alternative Methods
evidence.exact_quote: both text-based and multimodal approaches consistently outperform methods that are purely based on historical pricing, for both short-term (n = 3) and long-term (n = 30) volatility prediction.

conclusion.limitations: Small sample sizes for both short-term and long-term prediction may not represent broader trends or the robustness of the method across diverse market conditions.

claim.text: The HTML model's prediction performance always exceeds that of purely pricing-based methods.
claim.exact_quote: And, in the case of HTML, its prediction performance always exceeds that offered by pricing-based methods, regardless of n.

evidence.evidence_text: HTML's prediction performance exceeds that offered by pricing-based methods, regardless of n.
evidence.limitations: No comparison with non-pricing but non-HTML methods.
evidence.location: 6.1 Comparing Price-based Methods with Alternative Methods
evidence.exact_quote: in the case of HTML, its prediction performance always exceeds that offered by pricing-based methods, regardless of n.

conclusion.limitations: Lacks comparison details on how significant the improvement is or in what contexts (market conditions, data volume, etc.) it holds true.

claim.text: Text+audio data offers statistically significant benefits for short-term volatility prediction using HTML model.
claim.exact_quote: For HTML, the benefits of using multimodal learning are statistically significant for n=3 only, however (p ≤ 0.01).

evidence.evidence_text: The use of text+audio data provides statistically significant benefits for short-term volatility prediction (n=3) using HTML.
evidence.limitations: Statistical significance limited to short-term (n=3); no significant benefits for medium or long-term predictions.
evidence.location: 6.2 On the Utility of Audio Features
evidence.exact_quote: HTML delivers its most accurate short-term predictions using text+audio...[with] benefits...statistically significant for n=3 only, however (p ≤ 0.01).

conclusion.limitations: The evidence only supports the benefit for short-term volatility prediction; it's unclear if these benefits extend to long-term predictions or other financial metrics.

claim.text: Hierarchical attention model with bi-directional GRU notes distinct improvement in volatility prediction.
claim.exact_quote: With a bi-directional GRU model, we note a distinct improvement.

evidence.evidence_text: Applying a hierarchical attention model with a bi-directional GRU shows distinct improvement in volatility prediction.
evidence.limitations: Evidence based on comparison with other methods; specific quantitative improvements not detailed.
evidence.location: 6.3 On the Benefits of the Hierarchical Transformer Architecture
evidence.exact_quote: if we adapt a hierarchical attention network (HAN) with a bi-directional GRU model, we note a distinct improvement.

conclusion.limitations: While the claim notes an improvement, it does not quantify the improvement or compare it against other models beyond the hierarchical attention with bi-directional GRU.

claim.text: Hierarchical Transformer models outperform state-of-the-art multimodal models.
claim.exact_quote: It is noteworthy that HAN outperforms the state-of-the-art multimodal results for n=30.

evidence.evidence_text: Hierarchical Transformer model delivers stronger performance on all tasks compared to models without self-attention and mutual-head attention.
evidence.limitations: Comparison limited to attention-based enhancements; baseline comparison for multimodal methods unprovided.
evidence.location: 6.3 On the Benefits of the Hierarchical Transformer Architecture
evidence.exact_quote: The performance of our model is stronger on all tasks, suggesting improvements due to the progressive architecture of Hierarchical Transformer and the use of pre-trained word embeddings.

conclusion.limitations: The comparison to state-of-the-art multimodal models lacks specificity about which models were compared, under what conditions, and by how much the performance was improved.

claim.text: WWM-BERT embeddings improve prediction tasks in volatility forecasting.
claim.exact_quote: WWM-BERT has a beneficial effect on each prediction task compared to Glove.

evidence.evidence_text: WWM-BERT embeddings yield a beneficial effect on each prediction task compared to other embeddings.
evidence.limitations: Comparative analysis limited; specific performance improvements over other embeddings not quantified.
evidence.location: 6.3 On the Benefits of the Hierarchical Transformer Architecture
evidence.exact_quote: As might be expected, WWM-BERT has a beneficial effect on each prediction task compared to Glove.

conclusion.limitations: Evidence does not detail the comparative analysis with other embeddings, nor does it specify the contexts or datasets where WWM-BERT embeddings are most effective.

claim.text: The multi-task approach offers improved performance over the single-task approach for long-term prediction tasks.
claim.exact_quote: The multi-task approach tends to offer improved performance compared to the single-task approach.

evidence.evidence_text: Multi-task approach displays improved performance over single-task approaches for long-term prediction tasks.
evidence.limitations: Evidence specific to long-term tasks; does not detail short or medium-term comparisons.
evidence.exact_quote: the multi-task approach tends to offer improved performance compared to the single-task approach...especially for long-term prediction tasks.

conclusion.limitations: The claim does not specify which types of long-term prediction tasks or financial markets were examined, limiting the generalizability of the claim.

claim.text: HTML provides substantial performance improvements for both short and long-term volatility prediction compared to previous methods.
claim.exact_quote: The model [...] delivers substantial performance improvements, for short and long-term volatility prediction, providing a new performance benchmark for this task.

evidence.evidence_text: HTML achieves the highest prediction performance across targeted time periods, establishing itself as a new benchmark.
evidence.limitations: Direct comparative data to previous methods provided; however, specific performance metrics beyond MSE improvements lacking.
evidence.exact_quote: significant prediction benefits accrue to the HTML model.

conclusion.limitations: While HTML is cited as a new benchmark, the claim lacks context on the comparison groups, such as the nature and number of previous methods considered.

claim.text: HTML establishes a new performance benchmark for volatility forecasting.
claim.exact_quote: These results establish this as a new performance benchmark for volatility forecasting.

evidence.evidence_text: HTML delivers substantial improvements for short and long-term volatility predictions over the best available baselines.
evidence.limitations: Further research required for comprehensive validation across diverse datasets.
evidence.exact_quote: The model builds on very recent work by [46] and delivers substantial performance improvements, providing a new performance benchmark for this task.

conclusion.limitations: The claim makes a broad statement without specifying the data, timeframe, or market conditions under which the baseline comparisons were made.
